A SURVEY OF PRIMARY
BIOH1EDICAL PERIODICAL PUBLICATIONS
IN LATIN AMERICA*
The PAHO Advisory Committee on Medical Research at its second meeting
in June 1963, discussed some of the problems of scientific communication and
recommended that the Pan American Health Organization study the problem further
from three viewpoints; "First, what is being done to solve the general problem
of scientific communication; second, what are the immediate needs in Latin
America in this area which might be met, at least partially, by more or less
conventional methods; and thirdly, how PAHO can most effectively cooperate
with WHO in working towards a solution of the problem of world-wide communi-
cation in the health fieldJ'
With respect to the second recommendation-the Committee singled out one
area in which conventional methods in scientific communications are employed
and advised that a consultant be appointed to evaluate the desirability of
supporting significant primary biomedical periodical publications in Latin
America.
On the basis of careful selection and examination of lists of journals
issued by leading abstracting and indexing services it was found that very
few Latin American journals were being covered by all of these services.
Efforts were made to select those journals which were, or had the potential
to be, strong regional publications. Library records indicated that not many
Latin American journals were published on the dates printed on the issues and,
even if printed on time, they were distributed abroad by surface mail and thus
were available to scientists in the United States and other countries many
months late.
* Prepared for the Third Meeting of the PAHO Advisory Committee on Medical
Research, 15-19 June 1964, by Dr. Raymund L. Zwemer, Federation Societies for
Experimental Biology, Bethesda, Md., acting as PAHO Consultant.RES 3/4RPS 3/4 -2 -
The journals selected for study were;**
lo Acta Physiologica Latinoamericana (Buenos Aires) -Dr. Bernardo Houssay
2. Archivos Venezolanos de Nutrici6n (Caracas) -Dr. Werner G. Jaffe
3. Boletín Chileno de Parasitología (Santiago) -Dr. Amador Neghme
4. Revista do Instituto de Medicina Tropical de Sao Paulo -Dr. Luis Rey
5. Revista Latinoamericana de Anatomía Patol6gica (Caracas) -Dr. L. Potenza
6. Revista Latinoamericana de Microbiología (Mexico City) -Dr. J.M.
Gutiérrez-Vázquez
7. Six other journals published in Brazil were examined with Dr. Carlos
Chagas for a selection in the field of experimental medicine.
Recommendations a
1. The few journals which now or potentially are Latin American or
regional in nature should be strengthened.
a. Financial assistance could be provided by purchase of
five hundred subscriptions at the full rate from each
of the journals, including air mail postage to the
users. This would provide each journal with from
$4,000 to $6,000 for editorial and printing expenses.
b. Titles or abstracts of research papers should be sent
by air mail to the various abstracting and indexing
services, as long before publication date as possible.
c. Editorial policy ahould be designed to encourage more
and better regional and world contribution of papers
** The Editor of the Acta Neurol6gica Latinoamericana (Montevideo), Dr. R. Arana
Iñiguez, was also visited.-3 -
by prompt decision, prompt publication and wide
distribution.
2. PAHO might explore the possibility of a Supplement to the BoletTn
de la Oficina Sanitaria Panamericana containing selections from all Latin
American biomedical journals. If done with rigid criteria, this would soon
indicate which additional journals are the best ones to strengthen. A pattern
has been established by the Federation Proceedings Translation Supplement.
3. Those journals which are selected for the initial experiment of
strengthening should carry a brief note indicating a) that they are part of a
PAHO cooperative project; b) the source of financial support; and c) information
on the other journals which are participating in the initial experiment.
4. A curriculum might be developed for a two-week UNESCO-type seminar
on biomedical journal editing. This would be open to younger scientiste
interested in research communication problems. The usual procedure is to have
UNESCO handle the expenses within the host country and then have the travel
paid by each of the countries sending seminar participants.
Discussion
I. The general problem.
a) Input. It is important in any field to determine the total number
of potential contributors from the country or region in which the journal is
published, and from other countries of the world. Naturally, contributions
from other countries only come if' the standards of the journal are high, as
most authors wish to have their papers in good company. Another factor in
relation to input is the use of local versus world journalso. When someone has
a paper which they believe is new and outstánding, they wish it to haye as
wide an audience as possible and therefore are more apt to select a journal
which already has a wide distribution.RES 3/4b) Distribution. Every journal published must compete for subscription $
funds of libraries, for the subscriptions by individuals who normally limit
their needs to three or four journals, and to the possibility of exchanges.
For some countries subscriptions from other countries become involved in
currency problems and, as was found during the course of the survey, with
postal problems as well.
o) Announcement. The larger indexing and abstracting services, each of
which currently index or abstract more than 100,000 items per year, may not
be aware of the significant Latin American journals. If aware of them, they
are in competition with thousands of other journals. When the journal is
accepted by the abstracting or indexing service, the articles abstracted or
indexed will tend to be lost in the mass and represent a very minor percentage
of the total, if the number of research articles in each issue is small.
d) Use. One of the.most. difficult things to' determine Ls the degree
of use of a journal. One measure is whether it is used frequently in a library.
This can be seen by the condition of the journal, by the time it is ready for
binding. In some cases journals have been used so often that a new set must
be bought before it can be bound. Another measure of use is the number of
times it is cited by authors in their papers. The use of a citation index t
might give some measure from a quantitative point of view, but one must
remember that a new and outstanding technique may be cited many times, whereas
a good paper expounding a theory may be cited infrequently. If cited, it soon
will be incorporated in a review article or a book and thus cease to be quoted
as a separate contribution.RES 3/4 -4 -RES 3/4
II. Economics.
All of the Latin American journals examined had economic
problems of one type or another. In some cases, government appropriations
and franking privileges took care of printing costs and mailing, respectively,
but no money was available for editorial asaistance. In other cases, the
papers to be published greatly exceeded the number that could be printed with
existing funds with the result that both the size of the journal and the
number of issues printed were limited. The actual situation of the journals
under discussion is given separately in the annex.*
III. What can be done "by more or less conventional methods."
a) Local effort is needed to secure more and especially better
scientific articles. In the case of at least three journals,
stronger editorial policies have resulted in better papers
being submitted. These journals have enough material to
produce extra issues in each year if finances permitted.
b) Better announcement is needed at the time of appearance of
the issues so that the scientific community in other countries
is made aware of it. Announcements could appear in the Boletin
de la Oficina Sanitaria Panamericana which goes to about 12,000
Latin American medical and health personnel. For those journals
which have most of their articles in English, an announcement
can be put in the Federation Proceedings''Translation Supplement
under the heading "English Language Access to Foreign Literature."
The Federation Proceedings goes to more than 12,000 subscribers intheUS.
and throughout the world. Of these subscribers 1,500 are libraries
in the United States and 1,000 are libraries in other countries.
* Annex to RES 3/4--5 -It would be well to have each journal included in the PAHO
study prepare a short paragraph describing its activities.
After editing for uniformity these could be sent to the two
announcement media mentioned above. Another announcement
procedure which has worked well in regard to one of the
journals in the study is an exchange arrangement for publication
of tables of contents with a similar journal published in the
United States. In this way both journals become better known
in new areas.
c) Indexing and abstracting services can provide prompt and better
service if abstracts are edited and printed with each paper,
preferably using two languages. At the time the editor of the
journal has page proof, he should send duplicates of these by
air mail to the announcement services.
d) Financial help is necessary for one or two years.
It became obvious that none of the journals studied were completely
self-supporting. In some cases there was enough money for printing
and for distribution but not enough for copy-editing and other
control services. Others had the services provided by an
organization but there was not enough money for printing a
sufficient number of issues in a year. Those journals which
appear annually and semi-annually have great difficulty in getting
good papers because authors are not willing to wait for long
periods of time before their papers are published. An
examination showeda that the financial needs of each JournalRES 3/4 -6 - .,-7 -
differed and it would be difficult to go to a number of
foundations or to one foundationwith small, individual
requests for specific expenditures. Grants for specific
purposes might also interfere with the administration of
the journal by its editors and publishers. Therefore,
another solution has been explored.
e) Wide-spread distribution. Issues which are paid for at
the regular subscription rate plus air mail postage would be
sent in the Western Hemisphere to major libraries, medical
schools, and special institutes dealing with the subject
matter of the individual journals. The naeds of most of the
journals could be met by an amount of $4,000 to $6,000 per
year. If an arbitrary number of 500 subscriptions were
purchased this would meet most of the needs of the journals
in the study. A foundation should be asked for a grant of
about $359000 for the first year. Renewal for a second year
would depend on further study.
f) Formation of societies for which the journal would be the
official organ of publication. In the case of several of the
journals, Latin American organizations exist or are in the
process of formation. The dues of members of these Latin
American societies should be set at a rate which would include
a subscription to the journal of the society or federation.
Many U.S. journals have lower rates for society members who
are asked to keep these as personal subscriptions so as not to
reduce the revenue from libraries and institutes.RES 3/4PAN AMERICAN HEALTH THIRD MEETING

9. Remarks1. ACTA PHYSIOLOGICA LATINOAMERICANA published by the
Asociacion Latinoamericana de Ciencias Physiologicas. It should
be noted that the word physiology in the title is broadly interpreted
to include morphology, biochemistry, biophysics, pharmacology,
microbiology and biology except for taxonomic work. Potential
contributors and subscribers are located in more than two hundred
universities with professional personnel of more than 1, 100. This
would provide a potential of contributed manuscripts of 450. Actually,
only seventy-three manuscripts are received annually. Of these,
five percent are not accepted for publication. Screening is done by
an active editorial group of six Secretarios de Redaccion from Buenos
Aires. Editors located in several other countries are sometimes used
as referees but there are difficulties including postal delays. Authors
are given a great deal of service including scientific corrections,
copy editing for language, technical terminology, style and assistance
with figures and tables. The composition and printing is letterpress
with payment to the printer per issue. The total print order is 1, 000
copies; of these 394 are sent out in individual mailings. The greatest
number is to foreign libraries, then foreign individuals, finally indi-
viduals within Argentina and thirteen local libraries. Thirty-one
journals are received in exchange and placed in local institutional
libraries. It is abstracted by Biological Abstracts and indexed
by Index Medicus. As yet abstracts are not printed in the journal
with the papers. The articles-appear in English, Spanish, and Portu-
guese with a majority of the papers in English. Advertisements are
of professional quality only and in specified locations. The attached
budget shows that the journal is dependent on the Argentine Association
for Advancement of Science and the National Research Council to main-
tain a balanced budget. At the time of the interview, there were no
issues for 1964 and reports from other countries indicated that number
3 of 1963 had apparently been lost in the mail. The chief need of this
journal is for funds to provide more rapid publication and distribution
and to provide additional funds for editorial staff.2. ARCHIVOS VENEZOLANOS DE NUTRICION published by the Instituto J
Nacional de Nutricion. Primary journal interest is in human nutrition.
The potential total of contributed manuscripts from Latin America
was estimated at more than 100. Details of contributions from other
countries are listed in the attached paper prepared for UNESCO. It
showed that of forty-four manuscripts, twenty-five were of Venezuelan
origin, ten from Guatemala, five from Peru, two from Chile, one from
Ecuador and one from England. About fourteen manuscripts are received
annually and are reviewed by the editor with assistance from local ~.
institute staff of eight and three international editors from Guatemala,
Puerto Rico and Peru. Two opinions are necessary for a decision. About
twenty percent of the manuscripts are not accepted for publication. Of
the reviewers, two of the eight local and one of the three international
are really active and provide good reviews. The editor has no paid
assistance and his own secretary is used for correspondence and main-
tenance of records. A great deal of the editing is done in the evening
and week-ends with time spared from university and institute work. The
editor provides only scientific corrections and copy editing of technical
terminology. The language, style, figures, tables and so forth are the
author's responsibility. The journal is printed on good paper with
excellent illustrations using letterpress with publication by contract.
The total print order is 2,200 of which 1, 700 are distributed by surface
mail. Of these, forty go to domestic libraries and 250 to foreign libraries.
About 1,400 copies are distributed to individuals locally and about 100
individuals abroad. A large number of journals are received on exchange
and are deposited in the Biblioteca del Instituto de Nutricion. The
journal is abstracted or indexed by six major services. Abstracts are
printed in the journal with the paper and a summary is in a language
other than that in which the paper is written. Spanish and English
predominate although due to the.training of the editor in ZUrich the
journal used to carry German summaries prepared by the editor himself.
The journal carries no advertisements. Publication charges are
included in the budget of the Institute of Nutrition and distribution is
by franked postage. The situation would change if the journal were to
become completely Latin American. It has, however, initiated an
international section which is described in the paper prepared by
Dr. Jaffe for the San Juan UNESCO meeting. Conditional measures 4
for success would be the formation of a Latin American society of
nutrition with all members receiving the journal as part of their dues.
This would also increase both readers and contributors of articles.
The editor suggested the possibility of transfering the journal to
Guatemala where there is an active group in nutrition, but this would
lose the Venezuelan government support which is total for the journal
at present. The issue 1963, number 2 was in galley proof at the time
of the interview and there are a few manuscripts in for 1964, number 1.
The editor needs some full-time professional and secretarial assistance
and an effort to direct nutrition papers to this specialized journal rather
than being widely scattered in many journals of broader scope.3. BOLETIN CHILENO DE PARASITOLOGIA; this is published
quarterly by the Department of Parasitology of the University of Chile.
Because of the wide distribution and extensive use of this journal,
the potential source of primary research papers is very large. How-
ever, the actual number of manuscripts received annually is about
eighteen of which two are not accepted for publication leaving about
sixteen a year of original research articles. Requested notes or
brief reviews amount to about four a year. The entire editorial staff
is from Chile with six members of an editorial committee and eight
consultants used as referees. Some redactory functions are performed
for authors such as scientific corrections and copy editing. However,
it is expected that the authors conform to the instructions which are
published in the journal. It is printed by the Seccion Educacion por
la Salud del SNS. Volume 19, number 1 for the first quarter of 1964
was received by air mail shortly after my consultation in Santiago.
The format and cover had been changed. The total print order of
6, 000 goes to 4, 093 individuals and 988 institutions. A more detailed
break-down is attached. Journals received by exchange are deposited
in the University library which makes a contribution toward the journal
cost. This is an aclknowledgement in part of the value of the journals
received on exchange. It is abstracted or indexed by the major services
throughout the world and is on the open shelf in the National Library of
Medicine of the United States. An indication that it might be changed
to serve a broader audience occurred at the inauguration of the Chilean
branch of the Federacion Latinoamericana de Parasitologos (FLAP).
The Federation was established on the 6 of September 1963 in Brazil.
It is expected that additional national branches will be established in
most Latin American countries. If this journal were to become the
official organ of the Latin American Federation than the general
recommendation would hold that all society or federation members
be given a copy of the journal as part of their regular dues. This would
provide a broad base of support from other countries and its continuous
publication in Chile would not deprive it of national support which it
needs during the transition. Financial help will be needed in any
transition from national to regional nature.4. REVISTA DO INSTITUTO DE MEDICINA TROPICAL DE SAO
PAULO; This is published by the Institute which is part of the
Faculty of Medicine of the University of Sao Paulo. Fields of
journal interest include tropical medicine, parasitology, micro-
biology, experimental pathology and related fields. In this respect
it overlaps several of the other journals in our list. However,
with the emphasis on tropical medicine it is probably worthy of
separate support. Sources of research papers and potential :-
subscribers number nearly a thousand who could contribute about
450 manuscripts a year. However, only seventy are received
annually and of these fifteen percent are not accepted for publication.
There are three active members of the editorial board; five
selected referees and other specialists used as needed. Scientific
corrections are suggested to the authors before acceptance of
papers; copy editing includes language, technical terminology
and style, and the editor almost always assists the authors with '
figures and tables. It is printed by letterpress on good paper with
good illustrations, some of which are in three colors. The total
print order is 1,200 with individual mailing of 1,100 leaving a stock
of only 100 which seems tcosmall. Of the subscribers 217 are
Brazilian libraries, 515 libraries in other countries; there are
297 individuals in Brazil and 31 in other countries. Journals
received by exchange are put in the Institute or the medical school
library depending on the subject matter. It is indexed or abstracted
by more than eight major services. The abstracts are printed in
the journal with the paper in two languages. An additional feature
is the abstract card which is printed with the advertising at the back
of the journal. This encourages advertisers and also provides
a service to authors who wish to maintain their private lists of
articles of interest. Advertising is of professional quality only and
in specified locations. It furnishes a very large proportion of the
income of the journal and the fate of the journal was in doubt in
April because of a decree to nationalize the drug industry which would
have taken away most of the advertising revenue. The journal thus
was saved by the change in government. The budget is listed in
the attachment and shows a deficit which, it is hoped, will be met
by a foundation grant. A very complete analysis is attached since it
was written as a paper for the San Juan UNESCO meeting. This
journal should definitely print more pages and have more copies run
off and also requires some staff for administration. This is at present
done by the editor and his secretary, with copy editing by the editor's
wife. As with many of the journals the editorial work is a labor of ,
love and the initiation and maintenance of the journal is nearly always
the work of one or two dedicated persons.0': i5. REVISTA LATINOAMERICANA DE ANATOMIA PATOLOGICA;
this is published by the Sociedad Latinoamericana de Anatomia
Patologica. The fields of journal interest are pathologic anatomy,
experimental pathology and clinical pathology. The Venezuelan
Society of Pathology has about forty-seven professional and thirteen
student members and the Latin American Society about 169 membeis.
There is an estimated number of about 475 pathologists in Latin
America who could contribute manuscripts for publication. The
actual number of manuscripts received annually is thirty, of which
thirty percent are not accepted for publication, leaving eighteen to
twenty published each year. Screening is done by an editor with
selected referees. There is no paid editorial staff but the editors
or the referees help the authors with scientific corrections and
with a certain amount of copy editing. Composition and printing
are letterpress by contract. The total print order is 1, 200 with
a mailing of 505. Of these, 115 are domestic, 320 foreign. There
are thirty-five exchanges and the journals are kept in the office
of the journal editor. The journal is abstracted by two major
services. It carries abstracts in more than one language.
Advertising is carried in specified locations and is of professional
quality. The income is derived ninety percent from subscriptions
and ten percent from advertising and is spent entirely for com-
position and printing. Editorial and administrative services are
voluntary and mail distribution is by the franking privilege. The
estimated needs were $1, 200 for secretarial help to assist in
manuscript control, maintenance of the mailing list and corres-
pondence. They would also need $900 per issue for two additional
issues a year. A proposed three year budget would be $3, 000 for
the first year, $2, 100 for the second and $1, 200 for the third,
after which the editors believe that the journal would be completely
self-supporting.
n6. REVISTA LATINOAMERICANA DE MICROBIOLOGIA published
by the Association of the same name. Microbiology is widely inter-
preted since the fields of interest include bacteriology, virology, --
immunology, algae and protozoa. Although the potential for securing
research papers is great, in the five years of publication only 242
manuscripts were received with 179 from Mexico, thirty-three from
the United States and thirty from other countries. There are micro-
biological societies in at least five Latin American countries and
strong groups of microbiologists in four others. Therefore, the
potential greatly exceeds the fifty-five manuscripts received
annually. Of these, ten to fifteen percent are not accepted for
publication. Review of manuscripts is done by the editor with selected
referees. Due to various conditions most of these referees are in
Mexico. A great many services are performed for the authors
including scientific corrections and copy editing and assistance with
figures and tables. The journal is printed in letterpress with each
issue paid for separately. The total print order is 1, 000 and
individual mailings are 628. These are distributed to twenty-two
libraries in Mexico, seventy-eight abroad, 260 individuals in
Mexico, and 268 abroad. Of the journals received in exchange ten
are local and about fifty are foreign. The exchange journals are 4
deposited in the library of the National School of Biological Sciences.
The journal is indexed or abstracted by seven major services.
Abstracts are printed in the journal with the paper in more than one
language. Advertisements are of professional quality only and in
specified locations in the journal. A detailed budget is in the attached
paper which was prepared for the San Juan UNESCO meeting. It shows
that subscriptions brought in only nine percent; advertising nineteen r
percent and sale of reprints five percent of the income. Forty-four ,
percent was from an institutional contribution and there is a deficit
of twenty-three percent. Expenditures of slightly more than $6, 000
are divided equally between editorial expenses and printing and
distribution. This budget seems to be quite low for six issues
a year.
* v
7~7. O HOSPITAL was selected from six journals published in Rio
de Janeiro which were reviewed in consultation with Dr. Carlos
Chagas. The chart of analysis is attached. The journal Anais
de Microbiologia was also considered but it is hoped that the two
microbiology journals might be combined into one strong one.
The editor of the one published in Mexico has indicated his willing-
ness to have the Brazilian editor as editor-in-chief of the combined
journal.
O HOSPITAL has papers in the fields of medicine, tropical
pathology and biomedical sciences. This wide range of subject
matter provides many sources for primary research papers both
from Brazil and other countries. In addition to research papers
there are summaries of important papers published elsewhere
and book reviews. 360 manuscripts are received annually and
screened by an editor plus selected referees. About twenty percent
are not accepted for publication and about 288 manuscripts are
published each year. The editor and referees provide scientific
corrections and there is copy editing of language, technical terminology
and assistance with figures and tables. The journal is printed on
letterpress by contract. The total print order is 5, 000 with individual
mailing to about 3, 000 libraries in Brazil and 800 individuals. ,There
are very few foreign subscribers but 200 foreign exchanges. The
journals received by exchange are deposited in libraries of local
institutions. The journal is indexed by I n de x M e di c u s and by the
Centre de Documentation. Abstracts in English are printed
in the journal with the paper. There is no restriction on the type of
advertising nor on the location in the journal. The income is derived
from advertising, subscriptions and sale of reprints and most of it
goes for printing and distribution; very little for editorial and
administrative expenses. This journal differs from the research
type journals which represent most of those which have been reviewed
in this consultation. In connection with a general journal in medical
science we also looked at five or six journals in Buenos Aires in
consultation with Dr. Lanari. It is possible that the matter of
a general medical journal should be studied separately with careful
examination of similar journals in other countries.1,
8. ACTA NEUROLOGICA LATINOAMERICANA; this is published
by a group of Latin American neurologists and receives manuscripts ~
in all fields of neurology. From a potential of about 300 persons,
about 150 manuscripts might be expected per year. In addition,
there are requested reviews of special topics. Fifty-five manuscírip-ts
are received annually, of which thirty percent are not accepted for -
publication, leaving an average of thirty manuscripts published
each year. Manuscripts are reviewed by the chief and two associate
editors with some assistance from others. Authors receive suggestions t
for scientific corrections and copy editing for language, style and
technical terminology. The journal is printed on letterpress by
a commercial printer. The print order is 1, 000 with 420 mailed by
surface mail to sixty foreign libraries, thirty-five individuals in
Uruguay and 114 abroad. Only seventy-five subscribers paid in 1961-
1962. There are seventy exchanges of which sixty-eight are foreign.
The journals received are kept in the journal office library. Three Á
major abstracting services covered the most recent issue. About
fifty percent of the articles are in English and abstracts are printed
in a second language with the paper. There are about fifteen 4
national neurology journals in Latin America and thirty journals
elsewhere. The budget shows that $6, 000 went for printing and
distribution and $2, 500 for other expenses. Income was $1,400
from subscriptions and advertising. The budget was balanced by
$3, 000 from a foundation and the rest from the pockets of some of
the editors. The 1963 and 1964 issues should be combined, with plans
to return to quarterly issues on time in 1965. .

II49. RE MARKS
The UNESCO San Juan meeting has been mentioned several times in
this report. Consultations were held with members of the staff of
the Centro de Cooperación Cientffica para América Latina both in
Montevideo and in Rio de Janeiro. A special meeting in San Juan,
Puerto Rico was called in order to make a selection from the vast
number of Latin American scientific journals and to indicate those
which might be helped or were worthy of being helped. A preliminary
list of joumals so selected was given to me but no official list has
as yet been issued. In general, one can say that of the approximately
two thousand journals which exist, about two hundred can be selected
as outstanding. At this meeting there was also a meeting of theLatin
American Association of Biological Editors (ALERB). These editors
prepared a list in the field of biological sciences. It is interesting
to note that the UNESCO meeting excluded medicine but did include
a number of the journals being considered by PAHO. The three officers
elected by ALERB are editors of three of the journals which we are
considering in this report.
In summary, I would say that the original initiative of identifying
Latin American journals was done by UNESCO country by country
over a long period of time. This then culminated in a Guide to
Latin American Scientific and Technical Periodicals prepared under
OAS auspices which provided more than 1, 000 titles. Now the
UNESCO meeting in San Juan has indicated that there are many more
scientific and technical journals which were not covered, but that
the quality is such that of the total of more than 2, 000 journals only
a few hundred are worthy of serious consideration. Finally, a further
refinement of twenty journals in the field of biology was undertaken
by an Association of Latin American Editors. In contrast, in the field
of health sciences, your PAHO consultant has made a very critical
selection of six to eight j oumals for your consideration for support
on an experimental basis.PART II
